notes.note:
Firefox is getting a major Visual Redesign ([Photon project][1]) activated on the Nightly channel and which will ship with Firefox 57 on the release channel.


  [1]: http://design.firefox.com/photon/welcome.html
Accessibility indicator will now appear in the title bar of the window when Accessibility services are enabled
Allow users to manage the site data
Middle mouse paste in the content area no longer navigates to URLs by default on Unix systems
The browser's autoscroll feature now uses asynchronous scrolling, similar to other input methods like mousewheel, providing a smoother scrolling experience
The content process now has a stricter security sandbox that blocks filesystem reading and writing on Linux systems

Removed the Share button. If you relied on this feature, you can install the [Share Backported][1] extension instead.

  [1]: https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/share-backported/

## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 7
 - Windows 8
 - Windows 10

### Recommended Hardware
-  Pentium 4 or newer processor that supports SSE2
-  512MB of RAM / 2G of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  200MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.9
- macOS 10.10
- macOS 10.11
- macOS 10.12
- macOS 10.13

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - GTK+ 3.4 or higher
    - GLib 2.22 or higher
    - Pango 1.14 or higher
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
    - libstdc++ 4.6.1 or higher
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - GNOME 2.16 or higher
    - PulseAudio
text:
In October of last year we announced [Project Quantum][1], our effort to create a next-generation engine. Firefox 57 includes many aspects of this project, so we’re calling this release [Firefox Quantum][2].

Firefox Quantum is roughly 2X faster than Firefox 49 on the [Speedometer 2.0 benchmark][3], thanks to its new [CSS engine][4], its [“just right” multi-process architecture][5], the way it prioritizes your active tab, and much more. Firefox Quantum also includes a visual refresh – Photon – that looks and feels right at home with modern operating systems. To learn more about Firefox Quantum, visit the [Mozilla Blog][6].


  [1]: https://medium.com/mozilla-tech/a-quantum-leap-for-the-web-a3b7174b3c12
  [2]: https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/quantum
  [3]: https://mozilla.github.io/arewefastyet-speedometer/2.0/
  [4]: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2017/08/inside-a-super-fast-css-engine-quantum-css-aka-stylo/
  [5]: https://medium.com/mozilla-tech/the-search-for-the-goldilocks-browser-and-why-firefox-may-be-just-right-for-you-1f520506aa35
  [6]: https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2017/09/26/firefox-quantum-beta-developer-edition/
